item.title: Emergency residential power generator illustration
item.description: For residents who experience regular power outages, it's a good idea to set up backup standby generators that turn on automatically during an outage. Portable generators can also be used in place standby generators to power a house. This animation illustrates the various household appliances that can be powered by generators.
item.media:keywords: Next Animation Studio,Taiwanese Animators,News,Politics,Education,Educational,News & Politics,power,emergency,generator,TECHNOLOGY-PORTABLEGENERATORS/EXPLAINER

item.title: CERN Large Hadron Collider: How it works
item.description: Based on tests conducted at the Large Hadron Collider on the French-Swiss border, scientists at the CERN research center believe they have found the so-called "God Particle," the Higgs boson, so named because it gives other subatomic particle their mass. The Higgs boson has been theorized for decades but never directly observed. Confirmation of its existence would place it alongside other subatomic particles to have been observed within the Standard Model of particle physics. This animation explains how the Large Hadron Collider works. The existence of the Higgs boson was confirmed after analyzing data from the Large Hadron Collider, which is part of the European Organization for Nuclear Research (CERN).
item.media:keywords: Next Animation Studio,Taiwanese Animators,News,Politics,Education,Educational,News & Politics,CERN,Large Hadron Collider,Higgs boson,science,SCIENCE-CERN/EXPLAINER

item.title: Scientists find evidence for Higgs boson
item.description: Scientists at the CERN research center believe they have found the so-called "God Particle," the Higgs boson, so named because it gives other subatomic particle their mass.The Higgs boson has been theorized for decades but never directly observed. Confirmation of its existence would place it alongside other subatomic particles to have been observed within the Standard Model of particle physics. This animation explains why the Higgs boson is believed to exist.
item.media:keywords: Next Animation Studio,Taiwanese Animators,News,Politics,Education,Educational,News & Politics,CERN,Large hadron collider,god particle,Higgs boson,science,SCIENCE-HIGGSBOSON/EVIDENCE

item.title: Artificial pancreas: how it works
item.description: British researchers are developing an artificial pancreas that would automatically control levels of glucose in the bloodstream, obviating the need for diabetics to constantly monitor and regulate their blood sugar levels during the day and reducing the risk of dangerous blood sugar levels developing while diabetics are sleeping. The artificial pancreas is being developed by principal research associate Roman Hovorka and a team at the University of Cambridge. It would not replace the pancreas but would consist of an externally worn sensor that would monitor glucose levels and an external pump that would use a computer algorithm to calculate doses of insulin and glucose and dispense them based on changes in glucose levels. SOURCES: HealthDay News, University of Cambridge Metabolic Research Laboratories
item.media:keywords: Next Animation Studio,Taiwanese Animators,News,Politics,Education,Educational,News & Politics,artificial pancreas,Cambridge,medical,UK,health,science,diabetes,insulin,glucose,glucagon,SCIENCE-ARTIFICIALPANCREAS/

item.title: Cow bred to produce low-lactose milk
item.description: Chinese scientists say they have developed the world’s first genetically modified calf that will produce low-lactose milk. Scientists at Inner Mongolia University injected genes from bacteria-like organisms known as archaea into cells from cow embryos using the technique used to clone Dolly the Sheep. Fourteen embryos were transplanted into 14 cows. Five calves were born, of which three carried the low-lactose gene. Two died soon after birth. SOURCES: Daily Telegraph
item.media:keywords: Next Animation Studio,Taiwanese Animators,News,Politics,Education,Educational,News & Politics,cow,lactose intolerance,genetically modified,clone,China,SCIENCE-MONGOLIA/LOWLACTOSEMILK

item.title: Backpack makes transporting water easier in developing countries
item.description: Greif and Impact Economics together have launched the BackthePack movement and developed the WaterWear backpack to help women and children in developing countries transport clean water more safely and with less effort. The pack holds up to 20 liters of water, reducing spills with roll-down closure, and weights 7 times lighter than a 20L jerry can. SOURCES: wH2O Journal, Treehugger
item.media:keywords: Next Animation Studio,Taiwanese Animators,News,Politics,Education,Educational,News & Politics,Greif,Back the Pack,WaterWear backpack,USA,Impact Economics,developing country,Haiti,TECHNOLOGY-BACKTHEPACK/

item.title: Bones grown in lab could be used to repair badly damaged limbs
item.description: Stem cell therapy may be used to fix broken bones in the future. Researchers at private company Bonus BioGroup and Israel’s Technion Institute of Research have successfully implanted bones grown from fat tissue stem cells into rats. Human experiments are scheduled for later this year. SOURCES: The Telegraph
item.media:keywords: Next Animation Studio,Taiwanese Animators,News,Politics,Education,Educational,News & Politics,stem cell,bone,injury,accident,bone fracture,cast,crash,fat,fat issue,liposuction,Avinoam,SCIENCE-BIOENGINEER/LIMBS

item.title: Root canal procedure
item.description: A root canal is a dental procedure performed by a dentist or endodontist to treat a badly infected or damaged tooth rather than remove it. A root canal procedure is performed when bacteria infects tissue in the tooth’s pulp, which contains nerves and blood vessels, and spreads throughout the root canal, the cavity in the tooth that contains the pulp. A root canal typically takes between one to three visits. This animation explains how a root canal works. Source: Mayo Clinic, Bupa
item.media:keywords: Next Animation Studio,Taiwanese Animators,News,Politics,Education,Educational,News & Politics,root canal,tooth,dental,health,dentist,SCIENCE-ROOTCANAL/EXPLAINER

item.title: Human settlement on Mars by 2023
item.description: A Dutch group called Mars One plans to have humans live on Mars by 2023. Starting next year, selected candidates will be put through a 10-year training program preparing for living on Mars. The supply mission will use Space X Heavy to launch the communication satellite and supplement to Mars by 2016. The first 4 astronauts will be sent to Mars by 2022 and land on Mars by 2023. SOURCES: THE WEEK, Yahoo news
item.media:keywords: Next Animation Studio,Taiwanese Animators,News,Politics,Education,Educational,News & Politics,Mars One,Dutch,Space X,satellite,Mars,Red Planet,space,astronauts,Hohmann transfer orbit,SPACE-MARS/HUMANSETTLEMENT/

item.title: Solar cogeneration: a more efficient form of solar power
item.description: Solar cogeneration combines a photovoltaic and thermal module to provide electricity and hot water. Traditional PV systems convert about 15 percent of solar energy into electricity, with the remaining energy wasted. Solar cogeneration captures up to 75 percent, converting the waste heat into hot water. It can yield five times the energy of traditional PV systems. SOURCES: Solar Novus Today, GIGAOM
item.media:keywords: Next Animation Studio,Taiwanese Animators,News,Politics,Education,Educational,News & Politics,CongeraSolar,California,solar cogeneration,energy,solar photovoltaic,PV system,electrocity,SCIENCE-ENERGY/SOLARCOGENERATION

item.title: How small insects survive in the rain
item.description: A team of scientists from the Georgia Institute of Technology have discovered how small insects cope with rain. The study found that when a mosquito is hit by a raindrop, its body puts up little resistance. The mosquito simply combines wit the droplet and begins to fall. Water repellent hairs then enable the mosquito to free itself from the droplet before it hits the ground. SOURCES: BBC
item.media:keywords: Next Animation Studio,Taiwanese Animators,News,Politics,Education,Educational,News & Politics,Georgia Institute of Technology,Mosquito,rain,water repellent hairs,raindrop,SCIENCE-SMALLINSECTS/RAIN

item.title: Mystery surrounding Earth’s core deepened by new study
item.description: A new study has increased the mystery surrounding the inner workings of the planet. The study by boffins at the University of London and published in Nature, found that the solid ball of iron that forms the Earth’s core is losing heat 2-3 times faster than previously thought via a process called conduction. This suggests that the core could be solidifying much faster than earlier estimates. Source: NY Times
item.media:keywords: Next Animation Studio,Taiwanese Animators,News,Politics,Education,Educational,News & Politics,Earth,core,Mars,University of London,Nature,conduction,SCIENCE-EARTHCORE/CONDUCTION

item.title: Developing more effective migraine treatments
item.description: For a century, scientists thought migraines were a vascular disease. But now it is thought that migraines are related to a wave of overactive neurons that spreads across the brain, which in turn affects blood vessels. Researchers hope to use this understanding to develop more effective treatments with fewer side effects for migraines that can stop the wave of overexcited neurons. Sources: Scientific American, Science News, Mayo Clinic, University of Maryland Medical Center.
item.media:keywords: Next Animation Studio,Taiwanese Animators,News,Politics,Education,Educational,News & Politics,migraine,neuron,neurotransmitter,ion,pain,medical,brain,SCIENCE-MIGRAINE/

item.title: Permafrost melt releasing stored methane
item.description: Researchers from the University of Alaska at Fairbanks (UAF) have identified tens of thousands of methane seeps in areas along the coast of Alaska and Greenland. Some experts believe the escape of large quantities of previously frozen methane could lead to a swift acceleration in global warming. SOURCES:BBC
item.media:keywords: Next Animation Studio,Taiwanese Animators,News,Politics,Education,Educational,News & Politics,Arctic,permafrost,melting,Siberia,Alaska,Greenland,methane,global warming,CLIMATECHANGE-PERMAFROST/MELT

item.title: Study identifies how pigeons navigate using magnetic fields
item.description: Scientists have moved one step further to decoding the secret behind the superior navigation skills of pigeons. A new study by scientists at Baylor College of Medicine published in Nature found neurons in the pigeon’s brains react to changes in the intensity and direction of magnetic fields. They believe the neurons interpret signals sent from receptors located in the eyes, nose and ear, helping the pigeon to navigate. Sources: Discovery, Popular Science
item.media:keywords: Next Animation Studio,Taiwanese Animators,News,Politics,Education,Educational,News & Politics,pigeons,navigation,GPS,magnetic field,brain stem,Baylor College of Medicine,Houston,SCIENCE-PIGEONS/NAVIGATION

item.title: Egg laying ‘led to dinosaurs extinction’
item.description: The fact that dinosaurs laid eggs was a major factor in their extinction, a scientist has claimed. Marcus Clauss of the University of Zurich said the physical limitations of egg size meant that dinosaur young were comparatively small and had to compete with adults of other animal groups. The end came when a large meteorite smashed into Earth 65 million years ago killing all large dinosaurs. Source: The Telegraph, AFP
item.media:keywords: Next Animation Studio,Taiwanese Animators,News,Politics,Education,Educational,News & Politics,dinosaurs,extinct,eggs,University of Zurich,cretaceous-tertiary,mammals,meteorite,65 million,SWITZERLAND-DINOSAURS/EXTINCTION

item.title: Evacuated Tube Transport could take you around the world in just 6 hours
item.description: Evacuated Tube Transport is an airless, frictionless, maglev-like form of transportation which is safer, cheaper and quieter than trains or airplanes. Six-person capsules travel in the tubes and can reach a maximum speed of 6,500 km/h, and provide 50 times more transportation per kwh. A tube can travel from New York to Beijing in two hours, and make a round-the-world trip in just six hours. Sources: ET3.com, Discovery News
item.media:keywords: Next Animation Studio,Taiwanese Animators,News,Politics,Education,Educational,News & Politics,Evacuated Tube Transport,ET3,ETT,transportation,travel,maglev,electric,capsule,technology,TECHNOLOGY-TRANSPORT/EVACUATEDTUBETRANSPORT

item.title: ErgoSensor monitor detects improper ergonomic posture
item.description: Electronics giant Philips has unveiled a monitor keeps computer users in a healthier position. The sensor is built-in to where the webcam is located. It is able to detect a user's position and distance from the monitor, and gives advices on body posture. It also comes with a timed-break function that reminds users if they have been sat at the display for too long. When the user is away from the screen, the display will automatically switch itself off to save power. Sources: CNET, Philips
item.media:keywords: Next Animation Studio,Taiwanese Animators,News,Politics,Education,Educational,News & Politics,Philips,ErgoSensor,ergonomics,LCD monitor,health,tech,energy savings,display,sensor,TECHNOLOGY-ERGOSENSOR/

item.title: Geothermal energy: How it works
item.description: Geothermal energy taps reservoirs of steam or hot water beneath the earth’s surface heated by magma, friction or radioactive heat sources. Cold water is pumped into the reservoir, where it is heated. Pressure pushes heated water up to the surface. This hot water heats a secondary fluid via a heat exchanger. Steam from the secondary fluid spins a turbine to generate electricity. Sources: Economist
item.media:keywords: Next Animation Studio,Taiwanese Animators,News,Politics,Education,Educational,News & Politics,geothermal,energy,environment,water,power,electricity,SCIENCE-GEOTHERMAL/EXPLAINER

item.title: Inside the world's quietest room
item.description: An anechoic chamber in Minneapolis’s Orfield Laboratory holds the Guinness world record for the world's quietest place at -9.4 decibels. As humans can only detect sounds above 0 decibels, the chamber is virtually soundless. The room consists of a mesh floor, walls lined with meter-long sound-proofing wedges, and a meshed ceiling. Source: Minnesota Public Radio
item.media:keywords: Next Animation Studio,Taiwanese Animators,News,Politics,Education,Educational,News & Politics,Orfield Laboratory,quiet,quietest,Guinness world record,Steven Orfield,noise,sound,sound proof,SCIENCE-SOUNDPROOFROOM/

item.title: Wildfires more common during Cretaceous
item.description: Findings published in the journal Cretaceous Research reveal that during the Cretaceous, 145 to 65 million years ago, wildfires were much more common than previously thought. During the Cretaceous, temperatures were higher and there was more oxygen in the atmosphere, increasing the number of places where and how often wildfires would occur. These conditions also helped flowering plants, which evolved during the Cretaceous. Sources: University of London via Science Daily, BBC
item.media:keywords: Next Animation Studio,Taiwanese Animators,News,Politics,Education,Educational,News & Politics,fire,wildfire,dinosaurs,Cretaceous,nature,science,University of London,Field Museum,Chicago,SCIENCE-WILDFIRE/CRETACEOUS

item.title: Titanic: animated reconstruction of the sinking of the Titanic
item.description: On April 15, 1912, the Titanic was on its maiden voyage from the UK to New York when it struck an iceberg and sank to the bottom of the Atlantic. A detailed map of the wreckage created by combining by 130,000 images captured by unmanned submarines during an expedition in 2010 suggests that while the bow glided nose-first to the bottom of the ocean, the stern picked up speed as it corkscrewed to the bottom of the ocean. Sources: National Geographic, AP, BBC
item.media:keywords: Next Animation Studio,Taiwanese Animators,News,Politics,Education,Educational,News & Politics,Titanic,animated,reconstruction,sinking,sink,reconstruction,wreck,iceberg,BRITAIN-TITANIC/RECONSTRUCTION

item.title: Carbon capture and sequestration methods
item.description: Carbon capture and storage is a way to limit damage to the environment by carbon dioxide emissions. Carbon dioxode can be injected deep underground into saline aquifers, depleted oil or gas reservoirs, and unmineable coal beds. The gas can also be piped into the ocean. At a depth of 1,000 meters, it dissolves into the water. On the seafloor at 3,000 meters, where carbon dioxide becomes dense enough not to rise, it forms a “carbon dioxide lake.” Sources: Science Daily, National Geographic
item.media:keywords: Next Animation Studio,Taiwanese Animators,News,Politics,Education,Educational,News & Politics,Carbon capture and storage,carbon dioxide,environment,science,pollution,energy,SCIENCE-CARBONCAPTURE/

item.title: ‘Unique’ neutron star system’s activity captured by NASA
item.description: In October 2010, a neutron star near the center of the Milky Way emitted hundreds of X-ray bursts triggered by thermonuclear explosions on the star's surface. NASA’s Rossi X-ray Timing Explorer, or RXTE, observed some 400 such events between October 13 and November 19 on T5X2, a pulsar in the Terzan 5 star cluster. A study of the data will be published in the March 20 issue of The Astrophysical Journal. Source: NASA via Science Daily
item.media:keywords: Next Animation Studio,Taiwanese Animators,News,Politics,Education,Educational,News & Politics,RXTE,neutron,star,pulsar,NASA,T5X2,satellite,space,science,X-rays,thermonuclear,SPACE-NEURONSTAR/

item.title: Tyrannosaurus rex bite stronger than previously thought
item.description: In a new study published in UK journal Biology Letters, researchers at Liverpool University predict that a Tyrannosaurus rex’s bite is much stronger than previously thought. Researchers used laser scanners to digitize T. rex jaws and used computer models to reconstruct the jaw muscles of the T. rex and estimate its bite force. The study predicts T. rex had a bite force of 20,000 to 57,000 Newtons. Source: Liverpool University via National Geographic
item.media:keywords: Next Animation Studio,Taiwanese Animators,News,Politics,Education,Educational,News & Politics,Tyrannosaurus rex,T.rex,Liverpool University,biology,dinosaurs,bite,elephant,BRITAIN-TYRANOSSAURUSREX/

item.title: Asteroid could strike Earth in 2040
item.description: There is a 1 in 625 chance that a 460-foot asteroid named 2011 AG5 will strike the Earth in the year 2040, scientists have warned. The impact probability is based on an observation of only one-half of the asteroid’s orbit, and could change upon further study. In 2029, the asteroid must pass through a 62-mile wide window in space, or “keyhole,” in order to maintain its collision course with the planet.
item.media:keywords: Next Animation Studio,Taiwanese Animators,News,Politics,Education,Educational,News & Politics,2040,2011 ag5,asteroid,asteroid impact,space,collision,Earth,SCIENCE-ASTEROIDSTRIKE/2040

item.title: Ice Age flower brought back to life by Russian scientists
item.description: Russian scientists have successfully germinated a seed that had been stuck in the Siberian permafrost for around 30,000 years. The perfectly preserved Silene stenophylla seeds were found in ancient squirrel tunnels located around 125 feet under the earth’s surface. The ancient plants are subtly different than their modern counterparts with wider petals and more buds.
item.media:keywords: Next Animation Studio,Taiwanese Animators,News,Politics,Education,Educational,News & Politics,Flower,Ice Age,Russian scientists,back to life,30,000 years,Silene stenophylla,SCIENCE-ICEAGE/FLOWER

item.title: CleanSpace One satellite designed to clean up space junk
item.description: The Ecole Polytechnique Federale de Lausanne, or EPFL, has unveiled a satellite program dedicated to cleaning up space junk. The CleanSpace One program consists of satellites with a grappling arm designed to take out space junk piece by piece, making space safer for the ever growing number of satellites. NASA tracks about 16,000 objects that are considered space junk.
item.media:keywords: Next Animation Studio,Taiwanese Animators,News,Politics,Education,Educational,News & Politics,EPFL,NASA,Outer space,Satellite,SPACE-CLEANSPACEONE/

item.title: Artificial jawbone created with 3D printing technology
item.description: An 83-year-old woman's infected jawbone has been successfully replaced with an artificial 3D-printed titanium jawbone in a world first. The 3D-printing technology developed by LayerWise NV of Belgium used additive laser melting in which a 3D printer builds up a medical implant layer by layer. The artificial jaw was fabricated from titanium powder and weighs about 107g. The patient is now able to speak and function normally again.
item.media:keywords: Next Animation Studio,Taiwanese Animators,News,Politics,Education,Educational,News & Politics,3D,technology,LayerWise,artificial,jaw,3D printing,BELGIUM-3DPRINTING/ARTIFICIALJAW

item.title: Ocean wave electricity
item.description: Renewable energy startup Columbia Power Technologies recently developed a technology that generates electricity from ocean waves. The Searay works by using magnets and an electric coil to generate electricity from the rise and fall of the waves. CPT hopes the Searay, one of a number of devices in development that use wave power to generate electricity, will become the next 'wave' in renewable energy. Sources:Forbes, Columbia Power Technologies
item.media:keywords: Next Animation Studio,Taiwanese Animators,News,Politics,Education,Educational,News & Politics,lucia.chang@nextanimation.com.tw Pre-2015 content upload for Newsdirect Archive Site Pre-2015 content upload for Newsdirect Archive Site Comments Share FileEditViewInsertFormatDataToolsAdd-onsHelpAll changes saved in Drive $% 123 Arial 10 Wave electric,Ecofriendly,Renewabale engery,Columbia power,Save Energy,Columbia Power Technologi To enable screen reader support,press Ctrl+Alt+Z To learn about keyboard shortcuts,press Ctrl+slash Youtube Top 100 pre 2015 Top Discovery Videos Explore Wave electric,Ecofriendly,Renewabale engery,Columbia power,Save Energy,Columbia Power Technologi,SCIENCE-OCEANWAVE/EXPLAINER

item.title: Clams feed off Earth’s mantle near deep, low-temperature vents
item.description: Japanese and US scientists working from the Japanese R/V Yokosuka have found a species of clam near low-temperature vents in the Mariana Trench. The clams live at a depth of 5,620 meters in a subduction zone near vents where low-temperature water emerges from exposed mantle. The mantle reacts with the water in a process called serpentinization, producing hydrogen and methane. The methane produces hydrogen sulfide, which clams feed on. Sources: Mainichi Daily News, University of Hawaii
item.media:keywords: Next Animation Studio,Taiwanese Animators,News,Politics,Education,Educational,News & Politics,clam,Yokosuka,Mariana Trench,serpentinization,mantle,rock,hydrogen sulfide,science,nature,SCIENCE-CLAMS/SERPENTINIZATION

item.title: EU to use drones to catch cheating farmers
item.description: Authorities across Europe are turning to drones in a bid to catch farmers who may be ignoring EU farming regulations or claiming illegal subsidies. The drones can be used to catch offenders who have ignored regulations and felled trees or illegally dumped farm chemicals. Drones can also be used in places where a lack of clear skies makes using satellites unsuitable.
item.media:keywords: Next Animation Studio,Taiwanese Animators,News,Politics,Education,Educational,News & Politics,EU,Scotland,drones,farming subsidies,illegal activity,farmers,EUROPE-TECHNOLOGY/DRONES

item.title: Kepler 22b: earth-like planet discovered
item.description: NASA’s Kepler space telescope has discovered a planet in a habitable zone around a star with similar conditions to our own Sun. Kepler 22b’s year is 290 days long and scientsts estimate the surface temperature is around 72 degrees, although they are not sure if the planet is made up of water, gas or rock. Kepler 22-b lies about 600 light-years away from earth and is about 2.4 times the size of Earth.
item.media:keywords: Next Animation Studio,Taiwanese Animators,News,Politics,Education,Educational,News & Politics,Kepler 22b,new Earth,Kepler space telescope,NASA,habitable zone,goldilocks zone,SPACE-KEPLER22B/

item.title: Arctic ozone loss hits new record
item.description: Arctic Ozone loss this year formed an "ozone hole" similar to the one in the Antarctic for the first time, scientists report. The destruction of ozone was more pronounced due to an unusually long period of cold weather which speeds up the reaction between chlorofluorocarbons and atmospheric ozone. Source: BBC
item.media:keywords: Next Animation Studio,Taiwanese Animators,News,Politics,Education,Educational,News & Politics,Arctic,ozone layer,chlorofluorocarbons,UV-,UV-A,atmospheric ozone,CLIMATECHANGE-ARCTICOZONE/

item.title: How rotator cuff injuries occur
item.description: The world’s top tennis player, Novak Djokovic, heads to Flushing Meadows for the US Open this week. Despite his recent dominance, he has complained of a shoulder injury over the past weeks. Shoulder injuries are common in tennis because the sport involves consistent rotation of the arm. This makes the bursa and rotator cuff rub against the shoulder bone, causing inflammation and pain. Source: WebMD, Orthoinfo, Orthogate
item.media:keywords: Next Animation Studio,Taiwanese Animators,News,Politics,Education,Educational,News & Politics,rotator cuff,US Open,Novak Djokovic,shoulder,Flushing Meadows,New York,medical,SCIENCE-ROTATORCUFF/EXPLAINER

item.title: How hurricanes form
item.description: Hurricanes form when warm humid air rises from the ocean. Convergent winds force the warm air into the atmosphere, where it releases latent heat as it condenses into clouds and rain. The exchange of the heat from the surface creates a pattern of wind that spirals up around the eye of the storm, and the hurricane grows, powered by the ocean’s heat and evaporating water. Source: NASA
item.media:keywords: Next Animation Studio,Taiwanese Animators,News,Politics,Education,Educational,News & Politics,hurricane,weather,Irene,SCIENCE-HURRICANES/EXPLAINER

item.title: How lightning strikes happen and how to avoid them
item.description: Nine people were recovering after being struck by lightning in Florida on Tuesday, including 22-year-old Brian Owens, who was in an SUV, and eight people at the Discovery Cove theme park. This animation shows how lightning strikes occur and what to do to avoid being struck by lightning.
item.media:keywords: Next Animation Studio,Taiwanese Animators,News,Politics,Education,Educational,News & Politics,lightning,Brian Owens,Discovery Cove,Florida,SCIENCE-LIGHTNING/EXPLAINER

item.title: Earth may have had two moons
item.description: In a paper published on Wednesday in Nature, scientists proposed that two moons were formed billions of years ago when a Mars-sized planet slammed into the Earth our Moon and a tiny Trojan moon that inhabited what’s known as a Lagrange point 60 degrees in front of or behind the Moon. Eventually the Sun’s gravity caused both moons to collide, with the tiny moon fragmenting across the far side of our Moon. Source: Nature
item.media:keywords: Next Animation Studio,Taiwanese Animators,News,Politics,Education,Educational,News & Politics,Earth,Moon,science,astronomy,Nature,SPACE-EARTH/TWOMOONS

channel.item:
3403562 How a nuclear plant works A nuclear power plant creates energy that turns water into steam. The steam turns a turbine that is connected to a generator that produces electricity. Meanwhile, the steam is converted back to water and returned to the reactor core. Inside the reactor core are fuel rod contains pellets of uranium dioxide. Nuclear fission occurs inside the fuel rods, releasing thermal energy that turns the water into steam. To prevent overheating, control rods are inserted into the reactor core. Wed, 01 Jun 2011 11:14:00 +0800
